emphasis.docTitle: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails ( Caenogastropoda : Truncatelloidea : Hydrobiidae ) from Morocco

subSection.paragraph: MOHAMED GHAMIZI 1,5 , ANDRZEJ FALNIOWSKI 2,6 , ABDERRAZZAQ BOUDELLAH 1,7 , SEBASTIAN HOFMAN 3 , ASSIA EL RHARRAS 1,8 , NABILA ASSAD 1,9 , SOUMIA MOUTAOUAKIL 1,10 & ALEKSANDRA JASZCZYŃSKA 2,4*

Stygobiont and crenobiont minute gastropods representing the family Hydrobiidae ( Caenogastropoda : Truncatelloidea ), characterized by the valvatoid low-spired shell, were collected from one spring and four wells in Bouregreg region, NW Morocco . The shells were photographed and measured; shell biometry is illustrated with principal component analysis. Penes were illustrated and described. Mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit 1 (COI) and 16S rRNA, as well as nuclear 18S rRNA sequences were used to infer the phylogeny. The snails represented two genera, both new to science. Their closest relatives were taxa from the Iberian Peninsula, the rough molecular estimate of the time of divergence between these Moroccan and Iberian genera coincided with the Pliocene Flooding, which restored the Strait of Gibraltar to connect the Mediterranean Basin with Atlantic Ocean.
Key words: mtDNA , cytochrome oxidase , nuclear 18 S , shell , penes , stygobiont , molecular phylogeny , Pliocene Flooding

The Truncatelloidea are globally distributed and the most species-rich group of freshwater gastropods, minute in size, mostly inhabiting springs and subterranean waters, and still poorly studied. Morphology alone is often insufficient ( Szarowska 2006 , Falniowski 2018 ) for species delineation. Molecular data are helpful in species discrimination as well as the reconstruction of phylogenetic relationships, but are still unavailable for most of the species, and too few loci have been studied so far. The Moroccan Truncatelloidea , mostly Hydrobiidae , are recently extensively studied (e.g.
Glöer et al. 2015
, Ghamizi & Boulal 2017 ,
Khalloufi et al. 2017
,
Boulaassafer et al . 2018
,
Glöer et al . 2020a
,
Mabrouki et al . 2020
,
Mabrouki et al . 2020
, 2022a, b) and some studies deal with the relationships between the NW African and Iberian fauna (e.g.
Boulaassafer et al . 2021
,
Miller et al . 2022
). Perhaps the most poorly studied truncatelloid gastropods are the ones with valvatoid, low-spired shells, often less than 1 mm high.

The NW African fauna, especially that of Morocco , has connection with the fauna of the Iberian Peninsula. This is attributed to the present Strait of Gibraltar forming a bridge of dry land during the Messinian Salinity Crisis (
Krijgsman et al . 1999
; McKenzie 1999 ). The uplift of the northern African and southern Iberian margins, which was probably due to the roll back of the Tethys oceanic lithosphere delaminating bands of lithospheric mantle from beneath the continental margin (
Duggen et al . 2003
), blocked the passage between the Atlantic and Mediterranean, about 5.96 Mya. This resulted in the regression of the sea, whose water level decreased by more than 1,000 m . In place of the Recent Mediterranean there was a desert, crossed by the vast canyons of big rivers, with some water bodies too rich and others too poor in salt, thus making it impossible for marine organisms to inhabit the area. There is a discontinuity in the marine sediments corresponding to that crisis. There were at least ten sea transgressions in the Mediterranean during the Messinian ( Hsü 1983 ). Instead of the sea there were numerous brackish water ‘‘LagoMare’’ basins, big and deep, though brackish, habitats. Later, 5.33 Mya, the Pliocene transgression delimited the Miocene, initiating the Pliocene. There was an abrupt catastrophic transgression of water from the Atlantic, probably caused by gravity-induced slumping from the western margin of the Gibraltar arch into the Atlantic abyssal plains (
Duggen et al . 2003
).

Bouregreg watershed in Morocco extends over an area of approximately 9,800 km 2 , is limited to the North-East by the Sebou basin, to the South by that of Oum-Er-Rbia, to the South- West by the basins of the coastal rivers (Cherrat, Nefifikh and Mellah) and opens towards the West onto the Atlantic Ocean. Elliptical in shape, it is drained by four main hydrographic arteries, each draining an area of 4,000 km ² (Oued Bouregreg), 3,600 km ² (Oued Grou), 1,900 km ² (Oued Krifla) and 150 km ² (Oued Akrech). The climate is semi-arid, with an average annual temperature of 15°–18°C in coastal areas and 15°–17°C in mountainous areas. Average annual precipitation is around 400 mm in coastal areas and 760 mm near the village of Oulmes in the mountains to the west of the basin. The prospected sites include 13 river samples (R), 25 wells (P) and 4 springs (S) distributed in the Bouregreg basin ( Fig. 1 ). Five sites (4 wells and 1 spring) provided the material described in this article ( Table 1 , Figs. 2–3 ).

The snails were collected from wells by phreatobiological net ( Cvetcov 1968 ), by filtering subterranean water through a nylon net of 200 µm mesh and sieving mud and sediment, and from springs by cleaning the small pebbles from the sediment over a nylon net of 200 µm mesh. The snails were fixed in 80% analytically pure ethanol and kept in -20 oC in refrigerator. The parameters as temperature, pH, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, and total dissolved solids (TDS) of the water were measured in situ with a multi-parameter probe HI 98194. The measured parameters are given in Table 2 .

For molecular analysis, DNA was extracted from whole specimens; tissues were hydrated in TE buffer (3 × 10 min); then, total genomic DNA was extracted with the SHERLOCK extraction kit (A&A Biotechnology), and the final product was dissolved in 20 μL of tris-EDTA (TE) buffer. The extracted DNA was stored at −80 °C at the Department of Malacology, Institute of Zoology and Biomedical Research, Jagiellonian University in Kraków ( Poland ). Mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI), 16S ribosomal RNA (16S) and 18S ribosomal RNA (18S) were sequenced. Details of PCR conditions, primers used, and sequencing were given by Szarowska et al . (2016).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 1 . Map showing the studied localities.

FIGURE 2. Sampled localities. A. Spring 3 (S3), type locality of
Maroccohoratia bouregregensis
, a spring by the road, used as the source of drinking water and for irrigation of plots downstream and to water livestock; behind the landscaped wall is the origin of the spring where the molluscs were collected. B. Well 1 (P9), a well located near the houses of the village, water used for domestic needs and for livestock (see the livestock watering troughs near the well); has a small protective stone wall with a metal cover. C. Well 2 (P10), type locality of
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
, a well located in an agricultural plot dedicated to market gardening and olive groves, water used for irrigation. Rudimentary protection by pieces of jujube bushes.

FIGURE 3. Sampled localities. A. Well 3 (P11), a well located near a mosque place of prayer, protected by a coping and a metal cover. Water used for ablutions and domestic needs. B. Well 4, a well located next to new constructions (school) water used for construction needs; salt water not used for agriculture, protected by a coping and a metal cover.

subSection.paragraph:
Five specimens , collected at four wells and the source of Bouregreg River, were sequenced ( Fig. 4 ) for COI (479 bp, GenBank accession numbers PP079487–PP079491), 16S (400 bp, GenBank accession numbers PP081621– PP081625) and 18S (286 bp, GenBank accession numbers PP081646–PP081650). For COI, the test for the substitution saturation analysis showed an ISS value 0.75, significantly smaller than the critical ISS value (0.96), indicating that sequences are not saturated and thus useful in phylogenetic reconstruction. The topologies of the resulting phylograms were identical in both the ML and BI phylogram analyses; thus, we present the phylogram computed with RAxML ( Fig. 4 ). They represented two distinct species, each of them representing a distinct genus, since the p-distance was 0.133, typical of the intergeneric relationships within the Hydrobiidae , and in the molecular tree ( Fig. 2 ) there were other genera between them. The results of all three techniques of species delimitation were identical and clearly indicated the distinctness of the two obtained mOTUs ( Fig. 2 ). The MDCs of both new genera were obtained by comparing them with all the sequences belonging to the clade marked grey on Fig. 4 . Principal component analysis, computed for four characters and for 19 individuals, showed PC1 – eigenvalue: 4.02, variability explained and cumulative: 59.1%, PC2 – eigenvalue: 2.43, variability explained: 23.5%, cumulative: 82.6% and PC3 – eigenvalue: 1.15, variability explained: 15.9%, cumulative: 98.5%. Genetic differences are poorly supported by morphological differences, some differences existed for PC3, where the main component was the b parameter ( Fig. 6 ), indicating that
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
have wider shells. The Mann–Whitney U test did not confirm this relationship (Z = 1.939, P=0.0524).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 4. Maximum likelihood tree based on the concatenated sequences of COI, 16S and 18S, bootstrap supports (>60%) and Bayesian probabilities are given. Blue and green colours correspond to new described species. Results of species delimitation are also shown.

heading.emphasis:
Genus
Maroccoarganiella Ghamizi et Falniowski
, gen. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species.
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
by monophyly.

Diagnosis. Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with hardly visible spire and circular aperture below the half of height of body whorl, neither eyes nor pigment, flat and massive, broad penis with broad and not prominent outgrowth on its right side. Molecular Diagnostic Characters for COI: asymmetric: 81(C), 369(C).

Etymology. Both the shell habitus and penis morphology resemble Italian
Arganiella pescei Giusti et Pezzoli, 1980
.

heading.emphasis:
Maroccoarganiella touarguii Ghamizi et Falniowski
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph: GenBank no. for COI: PP079487–PP079489

Holotype .
Ethanol-fixed specimen ( Fig. 5A ), Well 2 Bouregreg2, 33°13’49”N ; 5°37’10”W , a well located in an agricultural plot serving for market gardening and olive groves, water used for irrigation, rudimentary protection by pieces of jujube bushes (Locality P10: Table 1 , Fig. 1 and 2C ), leg. M. Ghamizi, 12 April 2022 .

Paratypes .
Ethanol-fixed specimens: locality P9 ( Table 1 ): A131 ( Fig. 5B ) sequenced, five specimens in the collection of MHNM ( Muséum d’Histoire Naturelle de Marrakech )
,
voucher number MHNM22 ZTMH60
; locality P10 ( Table 1 , Fig. 2C ): A132 ( Fig. 5C ) sequenced, 20 left in the collection of MHNM
voucher numbers MHNM22 ZTMH61
;
locality P11 ( Table 1 , Fig. 3A ):A133 ( Fig. 5D ) sequenced, three specimens left in the collection of Jagiellonian University. Four specimens left in the collection of MHNM
voucher numbers MHNM22 ZTMH62
.

Diagnosis. Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with hardly visible spire and circular aperture below the half of height of body whorl, neither eyes nor pigment, flat and massive, broad penis with broad and not prominent outgrowth on its right side.

Description. Shell ( Fig. 5 ) minute, 0.51–0.69 mm high, 1.12–1.30 mm broad, valvatiform, formed by 2½ rapidly growing whorls, separated by shallow suture and forming low and narrow, proportionally minute spire. Umbilicus moderately wide, with older whorls visible inside. Body whorl growing slowly, adjacent to symmetrical, circular aperture. Peristome continuous. Shell thin-walled, whitish and translucent, glossy, growth lines nearly invisible. Shell measurements: Table 4 , Fig. 6 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Shells of
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
. A. holotype; B–D. sequenced specimens. B. A131 (locality P9). C. A132 (locality P10), D. A133 (locality P11; sequences’ numbers as in Fig. 2).
TABLE 4 . Shell measurements. Colours correspond to Fig. 4.

subSubSection.paragraph: Soft parts morphology and anatomy . No eyes, body with no pigment. Penis ( Fig. 7A ) straight, broad, flat and massive, proximally broadened, distally triangularly sharpened, a broad and not prominent outgrowth distally on its right side. Female reproductive organs unknown.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 6. Principal component analysis of the measured shells of two new species. The shell measurements are also shown. Abbreviations: a—shell height; b—shell breadth; c—aperture height; d—aperture breadth.

FIGURE 7. Penes of the studied mOTUs. A.
Maroccoarganiella .
B.
Maroccohoratia
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The species name dedicated to a deceased colleague that participated in the field collection: Professor Touargui member of AESVT Khemisset.

Differential diagnosis. The shell and the penis resemble the ones of Italian
Arganiella pescei Giusti et Pezzoli, 1980
( Giusti & Pezzoli 1980 ,
Delicado et al . 2021
). The Moroccan
Ainiella Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2022
(
Taybi et al . 2022c
), and
Rifia yacoubii Ghamizi, 2020
differ in the outgrowth on the left side of the penis ( Ghamizi 2020 ), absent in
Maroccoarganiella
.
Islamia Radoman, 1973
with its bi-lobed penis ( Radoman 1973 ) is evidently different. From among the Iberian valvatiform
Hydrobiidae (
Delicado et al . 2019
)
similar shell can be found in
Iberhoratia Arconada et Ramos, 2007
(
Arconada et al . 2007
), but the penis in
Iberhoratia
has conspicuous outgrowth on its left side.Another Iberian valvatoid genus:
Corbellaria Callot-Girardi et Boeters, 2012
has similar shell but its penis also bears prominent outgrowth (
Ramos et al . 2000
,
Boeters et al . 2019
). The Moroccan genera with the penis without outgrowth:
Ifrania Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) and
Pikasia Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2021
(
Taybi et al . 2021
) have shells with lower and less circular aperture, and their penes do not resemble the broad and flat one of
Maroccoarganiella
. Moroccan
Fessia Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) has the shell with much higher spire, lower and somewhat oval aperture, and more slender penis; also the eyes and pigmentation of the body is characteristic of
Fessia Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
), but not of
Maroccoarganiella
, although this troglomorphic adaptation is facultative and easily gained or lost ( Culver & Pipan 2009 ). In
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
the shell is strikingly different than in
Maroccoarganiella
, globular with higher spire, some of the paratypes illustrated by
Mabrouki et al . (2023)
could be classified rather as trochiform, not valvatiform following Hershler & Ponder (1998) . In
Menzella timedrinensis
there are eyes and pigmentation, also on the penis, which is bent, unlike our
Maroccoarganiella
.

heading.emphasis:
Genus
Maroccohoratia Ghamizi et Falniowski
, gen. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species.
Maroccohoratia bouregregensis
by monophyly.

Diagnosis. Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with tiny but visible spire and oval aperture expanded to 2 / 3 of body whorl height, eyes present but unpigmented, penis bent, triangular, sharpening abruptly, with broad slightly marked outgrowth on its right side. Molecular Diagnostic Characters for COI: binary: 262(C), 348(G); asymmetric: 75(C), 141(C).

Etymology. The name derived from Morocco and the Iberian sister clade
Iberhoratia Arconada et Ramos, 2007
.
GenBank no. for COI: PP079490–PP079491

Holotype .
Ethanol-fixed specimen ( Fig. 8A ). Bouregreg 2, 33°23’46”N ; 6°40’41”W , spring by the road used by people for drinking water and irrigation of plots downstream and to water livestock. Behind the landscaped wall is the origin of the spring where the molluscs were collected (Locality S3: Table 1 , Fig. 2A ), leg. M. Ghamizi, 14 April 2022 .

Paratypes .
Ethanol-fixed specimens: locality S3 ( Table 1 , Fig. 2A ): A130 ( Fig. 8B ) sequenced, one specimen ( Fig. 8C ) destroyed for anatomy; 15 specimens left in the collection of MHNM voucher numbers MHNM22ZTMH63 , locality P16 ( Table 1 )
.

Diagnosis . Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with tiny but well visible spire and oval aperture expanded to 2 / 3 of body whorl height, eyes present but unpigmented, penis bent, triangular, sharpening abruptly, with broad slightly marked outgrowth on its right side.

Description. Shell ( Fig. 8 ) minute, 0.57–0.67 mm high, 0.99–1.17 mm broad, valvatiform, formed by 2–2½ rapidly growing whorls, separated by relatively deep suture, and forming tiny but well visible spire whose axis directed somewhat left. Umbilicus moderately wide, with older whorls visible inside. Body whorl growing slowly, adjacent to oval aperture expanded to 2 / 3 of body whorl height, peristome continuous. Shell thin-walled, white and translucent, glossy, growth lines nearly invisible. Shell measurements: Table 4 , Fig. 6 .

Soft parts morphology and anatomy . Eyes present, body with no pigment. Penis ( Fig. 7B ) proportionally minute, bent, triangular in shape, proximally broad, distally sharpening abruptly to pointed termination, a broad and slightly marked outgrowth distally on its right side. Female reproductive organs unknown.
Etymology . The name derived from the name of the basin where the species was collected: basin Bouregreg in Morocco .

Differential diagnosis. The Moroccan
Ainiella Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2022
(
Taybi et al . 2022c
), and
Rifia yacoubii Ghamizi, 2020
differ in the outgrowth on the left side of the penis, absent in this new genus.
Islamia Radoman, 1973
with its bi-lobed penis is evidently different. From among the Iberian valvatiform
Hydrobiidae (
Delicado et al . 2019
)
similar shell can be found in
Spathogyna fezi ( Altimira, 1960 )
. The genus
Spathogyna Arconada et Ramos, 2002
, however, is characterised by the penis with distinct outgrowth on its left side ( Arconada & Ramos 2002 ).
Pikasia Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2021
have shells with lower aperture and massive body whorl (
Taybi et al . 2021
),
Fessia Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) have shells with circular, not oval and lower aperture, body whorl growing slowly, higher and broader spire, and penis with no outgrowth on its right side. The shell of
Ifrania Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) differs in much lower aperture, broader spire not directed left, and much more slender penis without the outgrowth on its right side. In
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
, as already pointed above, the shell is strikingly different, globular with higher spire, some of the paratypes illustrated by
Mabrouki et al . (2023)
could be classified rather as trochiform, not valvatiform following Hershler & Ponder (1998) . In
Menzella timedrinensis
there are eyes and pigmentation, also on the penis, which is bent, the penis is different in shape and without the outgrowth on its right side, characteristic of our
Maroccohoratia .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8. Shells of
Maroccohoratia bouregregensis .
A. holotype. B. sequenced specimen A130 (type locality S3). C. unsequenced specimen from type locality S3, destroyed for anatomical examination.

subSection.paragraph:
Despite the morphostatic mode of evolution dominating within the Truncatelloidea ( Davis 1992 , Wilke & Davis 2000 , Wilke & Falniowski 2001 , Falniowski & Szarowska 2011 , Falniowski e t al. 2012,
Szarowska et al . 2016 a
, b, Osikowski et al . 2018, Falniowski 2018 ), even the shell morphology distinguishes our newly described genera, monotypic so far, described in detail in the differential diagnoses. As stated above, the genetic p-distances between our taxa are within the range typical of the genus level (
Falniowski et al . 2007
,
Rysiewska et al . 2017
). In the case of such subterranean animals usually the high level of endemism is expected, although this was recently questioned, since interstitial habitats may serve as routes of expansion for the stygobiont fauna (e.g.
Falniowski et al . 2021
, Jaszczyńska et al . 2022). On the other hand, endemism seems more frequent in valvatoid hydrobiids (
Hofman et al . 2022
), which perhaps can be explained by biomechanical factors, at least in part ( Falniowski 2022 ).

Considering the geographic distribution of the Hydrobiidae , restricted to the SW part of the Palearctic, and some territories in N America and N Africa ( Wilke & Delicado 2019 ), the obvious origin of the Moroccan Hydrobiidae should be West Europe, especially the Iberian Peninsula. Our COI-based molecular phylogram is not well supported, thus exact dating cannot be done. However, some rough estimates are still possible. The K2P distances for COI were 0.136 between
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
and
Aretiana wolfi
, and 0.131 between
Maroccohoratia bouregregensis
and
Iberohoratia morenoi
, mean 0.133. This, applying the estimates of Wilke (2003) ,
Falniowski et al . (2007
, 2008 ), may reflect the time 5.19 Mya (million years ago), thus slightly less than 5.33 ending the Messinian Salinity Crisis (
Krijgsman et al . 1999
) thus destroying the bridge between the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa. The differences seem to confirm the divergence starting after geographic isolation but this conclusion is tentative considering the weakness of our dating estimates

This study was carried out within the framework of the CEPF Project “Improving knowledge on rare and threatened species in the Bouregreg watershed, Morocco ” which has among its objectives to improve knowledge on freshwater biodiversity and highlight the importance freshwater ecosystem services. The MHNM Authors thank the Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund for the financial support (CEPF grant n.111540) and AESVT Khemisset for their assistance. The study was supported by the grant N18/DBS/000012, from the Institute of Zoology and Biomedical Research, Jagiellonian University.
